webTitle: UK first-quarter GDP growth: what the experts expect

fields.standfirst: What leading British economists expect from the GDP figures to be announced next week
fields.body:
Simon Wells, Chief UK economist, HSBC

The UK will just manage to avoid a recession when the GDP figures are announced, but the outcome is far from certain. We are expecting first-quarter GDP growth of zero: but after the 0.3% fall in GDP in the fourth quarter, if the figure slips to a minus number it will put the UK in technical recession.

Whatever happens, the UK recovery will look painfully slow. However, things may not be quite as bad as they seem: the headline growth number should be dragged down by a collapse in construction output, while the all-important service sector should return to modest growth.

And if construction does wipe out growth, that could raise a few eyebrows because it will put the official figures at odds with other indicators of construction activity.

News of stagnation will do nothing to boost confidence in the economy. Prospects for Q2 don't look much better, as the diamond jubilee will be a drag on output, just as the royal wedding was last year. It may not be until the third quarter that the UK sees any growth.

Looking through the erratic factors, the recovery looks set to stay sluggish, restrained by fiscal tightening and low wage growth. With the Bank of England now more concerned about high inflation than low growth, it may sit on its hands until at least the second half of the year. At that point, we expect a further £50bn of quantitative easing.

Nicola Smith, Chief economist, TUC

Most surveys now suggest the UK experienced limited growth over the early part of the year. But that should not be mistaken for success. Our economy remains far smaller than it was before the downturn. Our recovery is the slowest in nearly a century. When population growth is taken into account, we remain in recession. Worryingly, there is little evidence of economic rebalancing. We have lost over 400,000 manufacturing jobs, business investment has stalled, our trade gap is growing and consumption growth is still set to be driven by rising consumer debt.

The overdue fall in unemployment must be set against another drop in full-time employment, record underemployment and falling wages, all set to continue until mid-2013. Jobseekers outnumber vacancies by six to one across the country, and by 36 to one in some areas. One in five young people is in neither work nor training. We should not kid ourselves that less awful news than we've become accustomed to expect marks a turning point. The need for an alternative to austerity and short-termism is as crucial as ever.

James Meadway, Chief economist, New Economics Foundation

Next week's official figures are likely to show the UK narrowly avoiding a technical recession – two consecutive quarters of declining GDP – thanks to stronger than expected growth in services. But by fixating on headline numbers we ignore fundamental problems. Outside of the top 1% of earners, most of us will see no evidence of any recovery, and face years of falling real incomes and insecurity.

Stagnation will continue, for three reasons. First, George Osborne's commitment to austerity. Indebted households are not spending, and private sector investment continues to fall, down by over £40bn since its pre-crash peak. The worst course of action for government is to also cut its expenditure. This creates a vicious circle of falling demand – as we saw in the 1930s.

Second, the private sector is poor at creating jobs. Evidence suggests that public sector employment took up the slack created by the 4m manufacturing jobs lost since 1979, but the public sector is now contracting.

Third, our economy remains excessively exposed to the financial sector, with financial corporations' debt amounting to over 600% of GDP. Bloated finance is a continual threat to stability. A recovery requires an end to austerity, public investment to create sustainable, secure jobs, and rebalancing the economy to shrink the financial system.

Chris Williamson, Chief economist, Markit

There's an unusually large amount of uncertainty regarding the first quarter GDP numbers. The survey evidence suggests that the economy will have grown at a reasonable pace, rebounding from a weak spot late last year, but the official data suggests another contraction.

It wouldn't be the first time there has been a big divergence between business surveys and official data. However, while survey data does not get revised, since 1998 one in three first estimates of quarterly GDP growth has been revised by 0.5 percentage points or more – highlighting the need to take official figures with a huge dose of salt.

The Bank of England appears to have already discounted the revision-prone GDP numbers, favouring the survey's more upbeat picture. A weak GDP number is therefore unlikely to lead to more stimulus.

The reliability of GDP numbers is a particular concern, because if Wednesday brings news of even a small drop in GDP, another technical recession will dampen consumer and business sentiment and could lead to further economic weakness.

webTitle: Barclays chief Bob Diamond to show good citizenship

fields.standfirst: Barclays 'citizenship day' will stress the need to win back trust from the public and from customers
fields.body:
Barclays is planning to hold a "citizenship day" next month, even as it prepares for a stormy annual meeting next week about the pay and tax of chief executive Bob Diamond.

The event is to be held on 23 May and will be used by Diamond to outline the bank's approach to "citizenship", which he set as one of his four priorities when he took the helm in January 2011.

The plans for the citizenship day – which he promised to hold when he announced the bank's 2011 profits – are being made before Friday's annual meeting, at which some shareholders are expected to show their disapproval of the bank's pay policies.

One in five investors may fail to back the remuneration report – which outlines Diamond's £17m pay in 2011, including previous years' deals, and the £5.7m tax liability the bank has paid for him. There may also be a protest vote against Alison Carnwath, the non-executive director who chairs the remuneration committee.

The annual meeting is also expected to contain references to citizenship – which Diamond has described as giving "young people their first job" and lending to businesses.

It was the theme of Diamond's BBC Today business lecture last year and again in February when the bank reported its 2011 profits. Just a few weeks later, the bank admitted it was at the centre of tax avoidance schemes that HM Revenue and Customs had shut down because it regarded them as "highly abusive".

Estimates are being made that between 15% to 20% of investors may fail to back the remuneration report – which encountered a 10% protest vote a year ago.

The official outcome of the votes will not be known until after the annual meeting and Barclays made changes to the bonus plan for Diamond, and the group finance director, Chris Lucas, this week in an effort to reduce the scale of any rebellion.

Shareholders technically have until 11am on Wednesday to cast their votes for the meeting, by which time the bank will be able to gauge the scale of any rebellion.

Standard Life, a 2% shareholder, has pledged to support the remuneration report after the move to attach performance criteria to half of Diamond's £2.7m 2011 bonus and the bank's pledge to bolster the dividend in years ahead.

The citizenship day next month is expected to involve presentations by Diamond and Antony Jenkins, who heads Barclays' retail banking operations. Diamond has previously talked about the need to "win back trust from the public and from our customers".

The bank will now more closely link Diamond's bonus to return on equity, a measure of financial performance. Diamond will have half of his £2.7m share award for 2011 linked to the return on equity in three years' time. Only if the bank's return is greater than its cost of equity (11.5%) will he take that half of the bonus. The same will apply to the £1.8m bonus awarded to Lucas.

The bank's return on equity was 6.6% and analysts are forecasting 6.3% for 2012. Barclays' first-quarter profits, which will be released on Thursday, are expected to be £2bn.

webTitle: UK swells IMF firewall with $15bn loan

fields.standfirst: IMF chief Christine Lagarde close to announcing she has enough contributions to firewall as Spain debates further cuts
fields.body:
Britain has pledged a $15bn (£9.3bn) loan to the International Monetary Fund to help the organisation boost its war chest to $400bn to cope with a fresh outbreak of financial turmoil.

Christine Lagarde, the fund's managing director, was poised on Friday night to announce that she had cobbled together enough contributions to build a bigger firewall after Australia, Singapore, South Korea and some leading developing countries agreed to take part.

Announcing Britain's contribution, George Osborne said the UK had always been a supporter of the IMF and was willing to be part of a "global effort" to provide an increase in resources.

The chancellor said the loan, which at just under £10bn will not require a vote in parliament, was in line with sums being pledged by countries that were not part of the eurozone.

The deal was struck after a brief rally in European stock markets following the IMF's commitment to step in with bailout funds and a better than expected business survey in Germany.

The Ifo survey of German business sentiment edged up for the fifth straight month despite the continuing crisis, which has recently centred on the ability of Spain, Italy, Portugal and Greece to survive their second deep recessions in three years. Spanish bond yields jumped above the crucial 6% level for the second time this week as prime minister Mariano Rajoy's rightwing government debated a further €10bn (about £8bn) package of spending cuts and increased charges in education and health.

"It's necessary, imperative because at this moment there is no money to pay for public services," Rajoy said.

The situation worsened in Greece after two of its top banks reported historic losses for 2011 after huge writedowns on loans to the Athens government.

A sovereign debt swap, orchestrated by Brussels and a group of international banks, blew holes in their balance sheets. Alpha Bank and Eurobank together posted losses of €9.3bn, about 10 times more than they are currently worth in the market. The losses left Alpha's core capital reserves at 3%.

At least €50bn of Greece's second bailout is earmarked to rescue its banking sector, with some of the money coming from the IMF. It is not known if widespread bank losses will force a fresh round of fundraising.

Although Lagarde has said the $400bn in new loans is for use in any of the fund's 188 members, the increase in firepower is seen by the US, Canada and emerging market economies as a fighting fund for the eurozone.

Labour and some Conservative MPs oppose the loan, but Osborne said it would be a sign of a "dysfunctional world" if member countries did not provide the fund with the resources it needed. "This is a loan not a gift," he said. No country had ever lost money by lending to the IMF.

Andrew Tyrie MP, chairman of the Treasury select committee, said the IMF was the "only fire brigade available to the global economy". Britain's contribution was vital.

Labour's Treasury spokesman, Ed Balls, said the chancellor needed to impose tougher conditions before providing more funds. "The IMF has a vital role to play in the global economy and should have the resources to do that job, but it should not be bailing out the eurozone when the euro area countries are not doing their own bit to help themselves," he said.

The chancellor said the four conditions he had set for a UK contribution had been met – that any loans disbursed by the IMF would be subject to the normal tough conditions, that the money would be spent helping countries rather than currencies, that other members chipped in and that the euro zone reinforced its own firewall.

Osborne said the loan would come from the UK's reserves, was not money that would otherwise have been available for public spending and would not add to the national debt.

Lagarde's appeal for resources exposed divisions within the IMF's membership. South Korea said it would match Britain's contribution, Australia pledged $7bn and Singapore $4bn.

The US and Canada have refused to take part, while Brazil linked its support to changes in the IMF's governance to provide a greater say for the fast-growing emerging economies.

Canada said that European members of the IMF's board should decide how to use the $200bn in the war chest provided by the eurozone, but that non-European members should set the conditions if the amount pledged by non-euro countries was also needed.

webTitle: Mixed picture for retailers Dixons, Marks and Tesco as FTSE records biggest weekly rise since February

fields.standfirst: Leading index rises 2.1% over the week despite continuing eurozone concerns
fields.body:
In a bad week for several leading high street names, Dixons Retail was a bright spot.

The company hosted a drinks reception for analysts on Wednesday with new chief executive Sebastian James, where it was reportedly upbeat about trading. It has recently benefited from good sales of the new Apple iPad, as well as customers buying new televisions ahead of the digital switchover. With the final stage of the changeover in the capital last week, it reported a 349% year on year rise in demand for digital products in its London stores during the last seven days.

Analyst Eithne O'Leary at Oriel Securities said:

The visit to the Fulham store on Wednesday evening revealed that Dixons Retail is enjoying current market conditions. An improved service ethic across the chain seems to be helping.
A confident new management team is making the most of the difficulties of its competitors in the UK. Under private ownership Comet appears to be struggling to secure supply and as a result it is presenting little challenge to Dixons in the UK at the moment. The short term uplift in demand for TVs is helpful but difficulties elsewhere in the group remain. We have little doubt that sales in Italy continue to be very difficult and we expect trading losses there to grow. A similarly grim picture can be painted for Greece. However, the strength of Elkjop's market position across Scandinavia means that profits there will remain strong. Following a better than expected Christmas, better momentum in the UK will ensure that Dixons can make its bond repayment of £160m in November 2012. We expect the shares to continue to make progress.

Dixons shares ended 0.11p lower yesterday at 17.84p, but they were up 2.5% on the week.

Other retailers did not fare as well. Marks & Spencer disappointed the market with a 0.7% fall in fourth quarter sales, after buying mistakes left it with shortages of coats, knitwear, blouses and even ballet pumps.

Investec yesterday cut its recommendation from hold to sell and its price target from 325p to 295p. In a note entitled Off the Mark & lacking Spark analyst Bethany Hocking said:

We are bearish for three reasons. Firstly, we do not expect a recovery in the UK consumer in the near term. Secondly, we viewed 2013 cost guidance as disappointing. We note the recent history of under-promising and over-delivering on this front, however, and so our 2.7% assumption is below the guidance range of 3%-5%. Finally, the jury is still out on the success, or otherwise, of the strategic plan.

Marks ended 7p higher yesterday at 362.6p, down 7p on the week. Tesco added 1.8p at 321.85p but disappointed investors on Wednesday after it reported a 1% fall in UK profits to £2.5bn. More bad news for the supermarket came as Moody's downgraded its credit rating from A3 to BAA1, albeit with a stable outlook

One of the biggest casualties of the week was SuperGroup. The fashion retailer's shares slumped 217.7p yesterday to 351.8p after yet another profit warning, partly blamed on "arithmetic errors."

Meanwhile retail sales for March rose 1.8% from the previous month, better than expected but helped by panic buying of petrol.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 27.60 points higher yesterday at 5772.15. It recorded its biggest weekly rise - up 2.1% - since the first week of February. The increase, after four weekly declines in a row, came despite the eurozone crisis dragging on, with Spain and Italy both coming into spotlight again on worries about their financial position. But with the IMF successfully boosting its level of funding as officials and politicians met in Washington, investors preferred to concentrate on the positive. But Angus Campbell, head of market analysis at Capital Spreads, said:

There's no reason to be complacent as we've seen in the past these rallies don't always last that long and we could quickly see the gains snuffled out in an instant especially if the situation in the eurozone starts to get out of hand again.

Banks were in demand yesterday, with Lloyds Banking Group 0.81p better at 30.1p after a buy note from Investec. Analyst Ian Gordon said:

It's hardly a ringing endorsement, but we are starting to take comfort from the fact that not only is Lloyds increasingly adopting a "warts and all" approach to disclosure, much of the sellside froth has come out of near-term consensus expectations too. Revenue decline continues apace, reflective of balance sheet shrinkage and net interest margin decline (for which 2012 may conceivably represent the bottom). Return on equity recovery will be painfully slow, but (whisper it quietly) the worst looks to be behind us now.

Elsewhere Man recovered some of its recent weakness which was caused by worries about its growth prospects following a fall in the weekly asset value of its key AHL fund. Its shares added 2.3p to 95.7p after analysts at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch repeated their buy recommendation, albeit with a reduced target price. Merrill's Philip Middleton said:

Historically, AHL was very good at delivering performance fees above our trend assumptions, albeit with some volatility. The last couple of years have been an anomaly here. Assuming AHL reverts to trend, at some point, Man is extremely undervalued.
We reiterate our buy on Man, with a price objective of 230p, down from 255p, reflecting the diminution of long run earnings power from the recent product performance.

Credit Suisse was also positive on the hedge fund manager:

We believe over the medium term AHL performance will recover and the suite of products offered by Man Group is attractive particularly as demands for funds in liquid formats increases. Consequently we view the share price capitulation as a longer term buying opportunity. Our target price is reduced to 130p from 175p reflecting lower earnings but still offers around 40% potential upside, hence we retain our outperform rating.

Prudential put on 7p to 762.5p on talk it could be looking at a bid for the insurance business of Thailand's Thanachart Bank, in what would be a $500m deal. Earlier in the week analysts at Pru's joint broker UBS suggested the insurer could benefit by spinning off its Asian operations into a separate company.

Engineer IMI added 18p to 992p following a positive trading update.

But Arm lost 22.5p to 585p after recent weakness at the chipmaker's customer Apple, and concerns about supply issues after a warning from US group Qualcomm. Ahead of its second quarter results next week, analysts at Liberum issued a sell note:

We expect Arm to report a quarter on quarter decline in its first quarter results, in line with market expectations. The recent strength in licensing is expected to moderate to a more sustainable level. We expect Arm to continue to de-rate on the back of increasing competition from Intel on smartphones and uncertainty on the ramp of Windows on Arm. Sequentially weak first quarter results are unlikely to trigger outperformance.

Satellite company Inmarsat soared to the top of the mid-cap index, rising 18.7p to 440.4p after receiving a delayed payment from US partner LightSquared.

The US business has run into trouble when its plans to build a new network were thrown into disarray on worries about signal interference. Now LightSquared has paid up an outstanding amount of $56.25m relating to the completition of phase one of their agreement. In return phase two has been suspended until March 2014, and LightSquared will not be required to make a payment of $29.6m which is also overdue. The moves will allow the US company extra time to secure the necessary regulatory consents to develop its proposed network.

The bid battle for Cable & Wireless Worldwide, down 2p to 32p, continued to develop. India's Tata Communications pulled out of the running ahead of Thursday's deadline, which was subsequently extended until Monday to give Vodafone more time to decide its next move. Analysts said this meant Vodafone was likely to make an offer, but it could well be a lowball one. Espirito Santo said:

We believe Vodafone could easily argue a deal is accretive to its own shareholders up to about 50p per share but, in the absence of a bidding war with Tata or another late entrant, Vodafone may not have to pay as high a price for CWW.

Meanwhile Cable & Wireless Communications, demerged from CWW in 2010, added 0.79p to 31.29p after a positive note from JP Morgan Cazenove. The bank moved from neutral to overweight, suggesting it could benefit from making disposals. It said:

Having sold off by a third from its February high, we see a value-led opportunity. With CWC now trading on a dividend yield of 16%, expectations for a cut appear broadly held. We forecast CWC meeting its 8 cents dividend guidance for 2011/12, then halving it going forward.
As well as dividend coverage, the other likely barrier to investor interest is geographic complexity (36 markets, with scale in Panama, Macau, Bahamas, Jamaica, and Maldives). Further disposals could carry triple benefits: simplify the story; show liquidity of assets; and reduce gearing.

Elsewhere Daily Mail & General Trust dropped 3.2p to 420.4p. Under a change in UK listing rules, it will be removed from the FTSE 250 and other UK indices at the next review in June, because its A shares do not convey voting rights.

Lower down the market, SkyePharma soared 44.13p to 85.5p after it received a $10m milestone payment from US group Pacira Pharmaceuticals following the launch of post-surgical pain drug Exparel in the US. SkyePharma is also entitled to further payments of up to $52m and 3% of net sales of Exparel. It also won European approval for its asthma treatment Flutiform.

Some of the smaller oil explorers caused excitement. Borders & Southern, which is drilling in the Falklands, added 8p to 131p, on hopes of a positive update from its Darwin well.

An upbeat statement lifted Desire Petroleum, 0.25p better at 29.5p.

But Rockhopper Exploration fell 29.5p to 351.75p on concerns about the size of its Sea Lion field in the Falklands, and a lack of news on a potential development partner.

Finally mining group Beowulf lost 2.5% to 14.125p. It announced local prosecutors would not press charges relating to a belated mining application for its Kallak site in Sweden, but the mining inspector has yet to make a decision. webTitle: SuperGroup shares plunge after new profit warning blamed on bad maths

fields.standfirst: Superdry brand owner blames new warning on poor maths, wholesale issues and more garments sold at knockdown prices
fields.body:
Another shock profit warning from Superdry owner SuperGroup, blamed on poor maths, wholesale issues and more shoppers buying its trademark T-shirts and hooded tops at knockdown prices from eBay and discount stores, has sent its shares plummeting.

While the company, whose heavily branded clothes are worn by celebrities including Pippa Middleton, David Beckham and Leonardo DiCaprio, insisted the latest downgrade was caused by one-off or short-term factors, City analysts have lost confidence in the numbers, with one describing the shares as uninvestable.

Most do not believe the brand is broken, pointing to strong spring and summer ranges and a new three-storey flagship store in Regent Street, central London. But fashion experts said SuperGroup, which burst on to the scene in 2004 with a shop in Covent Garden, London, selling US-vintage-style T-shirts, often with Japanese text, needed to raise its game.

"They are not making their collections different on a seasonal basis – one season looks like the next," said Melanie Rickey, fashion blogger and contributing editor to the magazines Grazia and Pop. "Obviously they have been expanding aggressively, but fashion waits for no man."

SuperGroup has long been criticised for its logo-heavy T-shirts and polos. Rickey said: "They haven't even changed the typography. Superdry has a niche appeal which has been very popular, but my feeling is they are less popular now."

In its third warning on profits since October, the fashion chain said it now expects to make a pre-tax profit of £43m in the year to 29 April, down from £50m forecast in February and the £47m it made last year. Shares in the company, which runs 80 UK stores and 145 international shops, crashed 38% to 351.8p. The group floated in 2010 at 500p, and at one stage the shares reached £18.99.

SuperGroup said "arithmetic errors" meant its profits forecast for the wholesale business was out by £2.5m. There is also a profit shortfall of £2m in the same division as a result of demand for stock from franchisees and wholesale customers coming later than expected, although the bulk of these sales will be pushed into the 2012-13 year. More importantly, a further £2m shortfall was caused by more shoppers buying goods on the eBay clearance site or at discount outlets.

Nick Bubb, an independent retail analyst, called the latest warning a calamity.

John Stevenson, retail analyst at Peel Hunt, advised clients to sell the shares, saying: "Against very weak comparatives last year – we calculate that like-for-like sales fell 8% against a strong clothing market – we view this as a worrying result."

Operating costs have gone up too, partly linked to the hiring of new executives, but SuperGroup (and the City) hope new finance director Shaun Wills – who starts on Monday - along with Susanne Given in the newly created post of chief operating officer will sort out problems in reporting systems and operational issues.

SuperGroup said retail sales were on target and projections for 2012-13 should not be affected. But house broker Seymour Pierce still cut its forecast to £56m from £64m. Stevenson lowered his forecast even further, to £45m: "With another profit warning that questions management control and market communication, we struggle to see the shares as being investable."

SuperGroup also issued a profit warning last October, blaming the botched implementation of a warehouse IT system upgrade that left stores short of stock.

Several analysts, including Oriel's Pritchard and analysts at Singer Capital Markets, who had been buyers of the shares, put their ratings under review.

webTitle: Tobacco giants fume at Australia's plans for unbranded cigarette packets

fields.standfirst: World's big four firms take fight against unbranded packs to high court as Australia moves to toughen anti-smoking laws
fields.body:
They have been responsible for some of the most famous advertising and marketing campaigns in history, but this week the world's big four tobacco companies found themselves on the back foot. In a global test case, they went to Australia's highest court to try to block plans for cigarettes to be sold in unbranded packets.

From December, all cigarettes in Australia will have to be sold in olive-green packs with stark health warnings, graphic photos and no brand logos. Only company names will be permitted in a small, standard font.

British American Tobacco, Philip Morris, Imperial Tobacco and Japan Tobacco International argue that moves to force them to use unbranded packaging are unconstitutional because they allow the government in effect to acquire their property – the trademarks and logos – without compensation.

The case has been watched around the world, including in Britain, where the government began consultation over unbranded packaging this week. On Thursday, New Zealand's government agreed in principle to introduce unbranded packaging for all tobacco products based on Australia's legislation.

Acting for Japan Tobacco International – the owner of Camel and Silk Cut – Gavan Griffith QC said in court that the new legislation would appropriate 100% of the back of each cigarette packet and 70% of the front. The company's rights to its trademark, including the Camel image, would be reduced to a "bare husk". "We say our trademarks are extinguished," he said.

The case centres on a part of the Australian constitution which states the "acquisition of property" by the state must be on "just terms". That is, compensation must be paid.

The government claimed unbranded packaging did not extinguish trademarks, but instead regulated their use. The solicitor general, Stephen Gageler SC, said legislation had been restricting the way tobacco companies operated since the 1970s.

Intellectual property expert Professor Mark Davison from Monash University, Melbourne, expects the government to win. "The tobacco companies were in trouble from the start," he said. "The government has no interest in acquiring the tobacco trademarks for its own use or anyone else's. Therefore, no acquisition of property under the constitution takes place with plain packaging."

The government said it would be "incongruous" for it to compensate a company for requiring it to act to prevent damage to public health. The chief justice, Robert French, suggested the risk of fatal disease from smoking put this case in a "different category".

While the case is specific to Australia's constitution, anti-smoking campaigners say a government win would encourage other countries to follow suit.

"The more countries that go down this path, the bigger the domino effect. That's why the industry is fighting it so hard, because they don't want it to go anywhere else," said Anne Jones, chief executive of anti-smoking group Action on Smoking and Health Australia.

Australia already had some of the toughest anti-smoking laws in the world, which have helped reduce the smoking rate to 16%. Advertising and sponsorship deals are banned, and it is illegal to smoke in public places including bars, restaurants and entertainment venues. In some areas councils have banned smoking in parks and outdoor areas.

Despite this, 15,000 Australians still die each year of smoking-related illnesses. In Britain, where 22% of the population smoke, the figure is 100,000 at a cost to the economy of £13.74bn, according to a 2010 report by the Policy Exchange thinktank.

The World Health Organisation estimates nearly 6 million people throughout the world die from smoking each year, mainly in low or middle income countries. By 2030, it expects this figure to be 8 million. China alone has 40% of the world's smokers.

Whatever the human cost of smoking, tobacco shareholders will not look kindly on unbranded packaging. Their stocks have been remarkably resilient in an otherwise turbulent economic climate.

In 2010 British American Tobacco reported an increase in profits of 5% to £4.3bn. Philip Morris International, maker of Marlboro, the world's biggest brand, reported a 15% rise in profits last year to £8.4bn, largely due to growth in Asia. The company's total shareholder return was a whopping 39.8%.

But how much would unbranded packaging damage their brands?

"Once you start to remove any equity element from a brand, it hurts, whether that's a distinctive colour, shape, graphic or name," said Peter McDonald, lecturer in branding at Sydney University.

While it makes it more difficult for people who buy the product to consider the brand in the same terms as before, McDonald says it will not be the end of the road for the cigarette industry.

"The tobacco industry will need to target customers in other ways. It may brand the inside of the box or change the shape or appearance of cigarettes to differentiate brands and entice customers," he said.

"Another option may be to produce a branded pull-on case for their cigarette packet that would act a bit like an iPhone case and would be instantly recognisable."

The high court has reserved its judgment but is expect to rule before the unbranded packaging legislation comes into force in December.

webTitle: UK retail sales boosted by petrol panic buying

fields.standfirst: Petrol sales 'one of main drivers' as volume of retail sales rose by 1.8% month on month, ONS says
fields.body:
Panic buying of petrol after Cabinet Office minister Francis Maude advised people to fill up jerry cans to beat a possible fuel strike boosted retail sales across the economy last month, official figures revealed on Friday.

The Office for National Statistics said the volume of retail sales rose by 1.8% month on month in March – and "one of the main drivers" came from petrol sales.

The monthly increase in sales by "predominantly automotive fuel stores" was 4.2%, the largest since January 2011, when motorists took to the roads again after being snowed in during the previous December. The statisticians said the increase "was a result of consumers purchasing more fuel in case the threat of a fuel strike in the latter part of the month came to reality". Maude faced heavy criticism after thousands of motorists queued up to fill their tanks, leading to some petrol stations being emptied of supplies.

Strong sales in clothing stores as shoppers stocked up their summer wardrobes early in March's unseasonably warm weather also helped to boost overall sales volumes, the ONS said. Sales in clothing and shoe shops were up by 2.8% on the month.

Even aside from the petrol panic, analysts said the overall tone of the retail sales figures was positive, with sales volumes 3.3% higher than a year ago. Excluding petrol, overall retail sales still rose by a healthy 1.5% on the month.

Richard Lowe, head of retail and wholesale at Barclays, said: "The tide may finally be turning for the high street, and with unemployment falling there is certainly a feeling the stability of the past few months is here to stay."

webTitle: Store Wars: John Lewis and Debenhams

fields.standfirst: Each week we look at retailers competing in the same sector. This week we pitch John Lewis and Debenhams into battle
fields.body:
Each week we are looking at two shops competing in the same sector and reviewing what they are offering customers: from how helpful the staff are, to the best bargains currently on offer.

Our review will be based on a visit to stores on the same high street, or online, so it will be just a snapshot of how the retailer is performing.

In order to get a better idea of which retailers are delivering and which are falling short, we would like you to tell us about your experiences of the same shops.

Some weeks, both stores we visit may do a good job, other weeks there will be one that stands out as being much better or worse. Your reviews will help us discover if this is a trend.

This week, department stores behemoths Debenhams and John Lewis go toe to toe. Please continue to tell us which stores you would like us to go to.

John Lewis

Background Having grown from a single drapery shop in 1864, John Lewis now covers most major UK cities, with 29 traditional stores and seven John Lewis at Home outlets. Across the past century-and-a-half the group has purchased a number of local department stores with the majority, like this former Bainbridge store, rebranded as John Lewis in 2002.

The visit 11.30am, 18 April 2012, Newcastle.

What it sells Clothes, cosmetics, homewares and electrical goods.

First impressions Lying inside the Eldon Square shopping mall, this branch of John Lewis has several entrances, with the most prominent leading into the cosmetics and perfume department. Despite having no windows it feels bright and airy throughout its four floors and contains an espresso bar, cafe and brasserie for customers looking for lunch.

What were the staff like? The staff in each department were able to talk confidently about the range of products on offer and gave good advice to potential customers, although a couple of those working in the electronics department were unnecessarily pushy.

Best bargain A 52" Sony 3D/HDTV had a hefty £350 discount, reducing it from £1,999 to £1,649.

What does it charge? Marc Jacobs Daisy perfume (50ml), £40.50; John Lewis 100% cotton white shirt, £25; Dyson DC19db multi floor cylinder vacuum cleaner, £259. It also has the John Lewis price promise, offering to match prices charged by high street rivals.

Where can I pay? There were numerous tills located throughout the store, meaning customers didn't have to stray far to pay for their shopping.

Is loyalty rewarded? No.

Lasting impressions A vast and excellent shop with a huge range of products all well presented and easy to navigate. It oozed quality, with the messages explaining the John Lewis product guarantees and customer service particularly reassuring. There were always members of staff on hand and eager to help, even at a busy time of day.

The only major criticism is that its clothes range is largely pitched at older people. While these are clearly John Lewis's core customers, some younger fashion ranges would be a good addition. Even so, it provides an almost flawless shopping experience.

Overall rating 9/10.

Debenhams

Background With a history dating back to 1778 when William Clark opened a drapery shop in London's West End, Debenhams has proved to be one of the country's most enduring brands. It took on its current name at the start of the 20th century and has since expanded to become a global brand with 167 stores in the UK and Ireland and a further 61 outlets in 24 countries around the world.

The visit 12.45pm, 18 April 2012, Newcastle.

What it sells Clothes, cosmetics, homewares and electrical goods.

First impressions Open for just two years, the shop has a high quality finish with an imposing glass entrance outside and another into the shopping mall on the opposite side of the store. The clothing department is divided by brand rather than by item, with high street names like Wallis alongside numerous Debenhams-owned brands. There is a coffee shop on the ground floor and a restaurant upstairs, both of which were popular with customers. The store was busy on the lower levels, with fewer people browsing the menswear section on the third floor.

What were the staff like? Very helpful – when an item I asked for was not available they immediately offered to order it in.

Best bargain A range of coloured Morphy Richards toasters and kettles were reduced from £60 to £45.

What does it charge? Marc Jacobs Daisy perfume (50ml), £45; Thomas Nash 100% cotton white shirt, £25; Dyson DC19db multi floor cylinder vacuum cleaner, £259.

Where can I pay? There were tills across the store's four floors.

Is loyalty rewarded? Since leaving the Nectar scheme in 2008 there has been no general loyalty card, although a Beauty Club card allows shoppers to earn points on beauty and fragrance purchases.

Lasting impressions Debenhams' range was small but solid in most departments, with a larger selection of clothes and accessories taking up around half the store. The electrical department on the top floor was a little lacklustre compared to John Lewis's, but contained a decent range of products at competitive prices.

There was a wealth of special offers available: a blue cross sale offered 70% discount on selected clothing lines, while a separate 20% off sale covered several other areas of the store and included everything from photo frames to frying pans.

Overall rating 7/10

Adam's verdict Both shops offered a very good shopping experience and were clean and well presented. The staff in both were helpful, although the number of employees in John Lewis far outnumbered its rival.

John Lewis also had a far bigger range, particularly in its electrical department, but Debenhams won on choice in cosmetics and beauty, although a random price comparison suggested they were slightly dearer than John Lewis.

Debenhams' clothing section was generally good, but was confused by the number of different own brands on offer in certain areas. In men's shirts, for example, several Debenhams-owned brands sat next to each other despite having little discernible difference in quality or price; in comparison John Lewis had a single own-brand offering which was easily recognisable against the famous labels.

Overall, both stores were very good, but Debenhams couldn't match the range and expertise on offer in John Lewis.

Last time

The battle of the home improvement specialists saw B&Q trounce Homebase with 70.6% of the 942 votes cast.

whodhavethoughtit had this to say about the two rivals:

"All the branches of Homebase I have ever visited always look as though they are about to go into liquidation at any moment: limp, dying plant specimens in the garden section; swathes of empty shelves; nothing I want is ever in stock; bored listless staff (if you can find one - and of course they may be worried about their future employment). I could go on but I won't. In comparison B&Q is excellent and their policy of employing older workers who know what they are talking about is a real plus point."

Cheesyrider, on the other hand, didn't recognise our reviewer's experience of B&Q:

"The ones near me (North London) are non-descript tin sheds with no staff in them (tellingly the ones on duty are generally dealing with refuds)."

Many of you thought both B&Q and Homebase expensive, and had good things to say about other DIY outlets, with Screwfix in particular getting a few shouts. Glide, for example, said:

"I wouldn't bother with either as first port of call, as they're both expensive in my opinion. B&Q trade is also expensive. Electricals breathtakingly so.
I would always try Screwfix and Wickes first."

Let us know which of today's stores you favour, or if you aren't a fan of either or think another store offers better choice or prices.

webTitle: William Hill's mobile app brings in new customers and helps profits race ahead

fields.standfirst: Apple store success lifts revenues, while bookmaker also launches new mobile bingo game
fields.body:
Bookmaker William Hill has raced up more than 3% after a profits surge boosted by its mobile application.

In one week the company booked £11m of mobile turnover, thanks to its Sportsbook app now being available in the Apple store. Chief executive Ralph Topping said:

[The app has given us] access to thousands of new customers who have never bet with William Hill before, highlighting the growth potential of these new channels and their importance to our multi-channel offering.

In fact, the mobile app has been downloaded 190,000 times from the Apple store so far, with 30% of the customers being new to William Hill. It has also expanded its mobile offering with a bingo launch.

So first quarter revenues rose 12% and operating profit was 19% higher. The shares have climbed 9p to 275.8p, making it one of the biggest risers in the FTSE 250. Simon French at Panmure Gordon said:

William Hill has reported a better than expected first quarter performance. Online was the star performer with profit up 29%. Retail profit is up 8% helped by an impressive gross win margin of 19.4%. The group remains confident of meeting full year expectations of £296m EBITA. The stock is inexpensive on a 2012 estimated PE of 10.5 times... and yields 3.8%. We reiterate our buy recommendation and 280p target price.

webTitle: SuperGroup shares lose 40% after profit warning blamed on "arithmetic errors"

fields.standfirst: Company says difficult to predict wholesale business accurately and warns of £2.5m adding up mistake
fields.body:
Shares in SuperGroup, the company behind the Superdry label once beloved of David Beckham and Zac Efron, have lost nearly half their value after it shocked the City with a profit warning it blamed on "arithmetic errors."

The company said it now expected profits of £43m, having forecast £50m in February. It blamed errors at the wholesaling business amounting to £2.5m, plus a £2m shortfall in the division due to sales being pushed into the next year. On top of that, its retail business has been hit for £2m because of increasing operating costs and lower margins.

All this follows a profit warning in October which it blamed on problems with a new warehouse IT system which left its stores short of stock.

This latest announcement has a touch of desperation in its explanation of the problems at the wholesaling division:

[This business] is multi-dimensional, experiencing high growth levels and, given our rapid expansion and lack of history, it is difficult to predict accurately.

The company has been without a finance director since 20 March when Chas Howes stood down for a "less demanding" role, with replacement Shaun Wills joining the board on Monday.

Perhaps his first task should be to find a calculator that works.

SuperGroup's shares, which reached more than £16 at their peak slumped 245.5p to 324p.

Analysts were scathing. John Stevenson at Peel Hunt said:

With another profit warning that questions management control and market communication, we have no confidence in delivery or market expectations, and struggle to see the shares as being investible. Downgrade to sell [from hold].

At Singer Capital Markets, Matthew McEachran said:

This latest calamity in SuperGroup's short life as a listed company is not going to be well received today and the shares will come under severe pressure. We had put faith in the growth story but are placing our estimates and recommendation under review after this latest issue.

Elsewhere the market is trying to edge higher despite more worries about the eurozone, and another rise in Spanish bond yields. The FTSE 100 is currently 5.06 points higher at 5749.61, with engineer IMI lifted by a positive trading update, adding 29p to £10.03.

But Arm has fallen 15.5p to 592p after recent weakness at the chipmaker's customer Apple, and a downgrade to underperform from Jefferies. There were also concerns about supply issues after a warning from US group Qualcomm.

webTitle: International Airlines Group completes bmi acquisition

fields.standfirst: British Airways' parent gets 'significant' discount after two unwanted subsidiaries – bmibaby and bmi Regional – are folded into deal
fields.body:
International Airlines Group, the parent of British Airways, has completed the acquisition of bmi but will receive a "significant" discount after two unwanted subsidiaries were folded into the deal.

IAG had intended to buy the Heathrow-based bmi mainline business from Germany's Lufthansa without the bmibaby and bmi Regional units. However, Lufthansa failed to secure buyers for the smaller carriers in time and has sold them to IAG in exchange for an undisclosed price reduction – in effect paying IAG to take them off its hands. Under the original terms of the deal, announced last year, IAG agreed to pay £172.5m for bmi.

In a statement on Friday morning, IAG indicated that Lufthansa is paying for the airlines' ongoing losses as it said the cost of operating bmibaby and bmi Regional would be offset by the price reduction. "As previously stated, bmibaby and bmi Regional are not part of IAG's long-term plans and will not be integrated into British Airways. IAG will pursue options to exit these businesses and more details will be provided in due course," said IAG. BA has announced that about 1,200 staff at bmi, out of a total of 2,700 employees, will lose their jobs following the takeover. Most of the redundancies will come at bmi's Castle Donington headquarters in Leicestershire and at regional airports, with its Heathrow operations escaping the worst of the cuts.

Douglas McNeill, analyst at Charles Stanley Securities, said the discount would have been a key factor for IAG in closing the deal. "They would have been a lot less willing to do the deal if Lufthansa was not going to bear those costs." He added: "The reduction in price is effectively Lufthansa paying for the cost of the losses of these two units, and quite possibly the cost of closing them down." It is estimated that bmibaby and bmi Regional lose a combined total of €100m (£82m) per year, with bmi mainline losing the same amount.

Oliver Richardson, national officer at the Unite trade union, urged BA not to close the smaller carriers. "If BA is not commited to retaining bmi regional and bmibaby and the 800 jobs which are at stake, it must find a viable buyer. BA must do everything possible to give these two businesses and the workforce a long-term future in the UK aviation industry."

Bmi Regional flies from airports including Aberdeen, Glasgow, Manchester and East Midlands to 14 destinations. Bmibaby, a low-cost operation, operates from East Midlands, Birmingham and Belfast City to 36 destinations, including Ibiza, Corfu and Dubrovnik. In February, bmi said it was close to selling bmibaby to a "UK-based company". However, the deal has not been completed.

Bmibaby, a low-cost operation, operates from East Midlands, Birmingham and Belfast City to 36 destinations, including Ibiza, Corfu and Dubrovnik. In February, bmi said it was close to selling bmibaby to a "UK-based company". However, the deal has not been completed.
